greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangular array T(n,k) = Fibonacci(n+1-k)*C(n,k-1), k = 1..n; n >= 1.
comment: Row sums yield the even-subscripted Fibonacci numbers (A001906).
Row n shows the coefficients of the numerator of the n-th derivative of c(n)/(x^2+x-1), where c(n) = ((-1)^(n + 1))/n!; see the Mathematica program. - _Clark Kimberling_, Oct 22 2019
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n = 1..100 of triangle, flattened
formula: With an offset of 0, the row polynomials F(n,x) = Sum_{k = 0..n} C(n,k)*Fibonacci(n-k)*x^k satisfy F(n,x)*L(n,x) = F(2*n,x), where L(n,x) = Sum_{k = 0..n} C(n,k)*Lucas(n-k)*x^k.
Sequence {F(n,r)}n>=1 gives the r th binomial transform of the Fibonacci numbers: r = 1 gives A001906, r = 2 gives A030191, r = 3 gives A099453, r = 4 gives A081574, r = 5 gives A081574.
F(n,1/phi) = (-1)^(n-1)*F(n,-phi) = sqrt(5)^(n-1) for n >= 1, where phi = (1 + sqrt(5))/2.
The polynomials F(n,-x) satisfy a Riemann hypothesis: the zeros of F(n,-x) lie on the vertical line Re x = 1/2 in the complex plane.
Working with an offset of 0, the n-th row polynomial F(n,x) = 1/sqrt(5)*( (x + phi)^n - (x - 1/phi)^n ), where phi = (1 + sqrt(5))/2.
F(n,x) is a divisibility sequence of polynomials, that is, if n divides m then F(n,x) divides F(m,x) in the polynomial ring Z[x]. (End)
F(n,x) is a strong divisibility sequence of polynomials; that is,
gcd(F(x,h),F(x,k)) = F(x,gcd(h,k)) for h,k >= 1.  Thus, if x is an integer, then F(n,x) is a strong divisibility sequence of integers; e.g., for x=3, we have A099453. (End)
maple: with(combinat): T:=(n,k)->binomial(n,k-1)*fibonacci(n+1-k): for n from 1 to 11 do seq(T(n,k),k=1..n) od; # yields sequence in triangular form # _Emeric Deutsch_
mathematica: (* Next program outputs polynomials having coefficients T(n,k) *)
g[x_, n_] := Numerator[(-1)^(n + 1) Factor[D[1/(1 - x - x^2), {x, n}]]]
program: (MAGMA) /* As triangle */ [[Fibonacci(n+1-k)*Binomial(n,k-1): k in [1..n]]: n in [1.. 15]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 15 2017
for(n=1,12, for(k=1,n, print1(T(n,k), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Oct 30 2019
(Sage) [[binomial(n,k-1)*fibonacci(n-k+1) for k in (1..n)] for n in (1..12)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Oct 30 2019
(GAP) Flat(List([1..12], n-> List([1..n], k-> Binomial(n,k-1)* Fibonacci(n-k+1) ))); # _G. C. Greubel_, Oct 30 2019
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_, May 03 2004
ext: Error in expansion of generating function corrected by _Peter Bala_, Sep 24 2008
